00020     
00021     /**
00022      *  Execute a single command remotely using ssh and 
00023      * display its output, optionally returning its exit 
00024      * status (like passthru)
00025      *
00026      *  This function is intended to be used as a one-time
00027      * all-at-once non-interactive execution mechanism which
00028      * will run the command remotely and display its output.
00029      *
00030      *  If you try to issue an interactive command using this
00031      * function, all you will get is unneccessary trouble. So
00032      * don't!
00033      *
00034      *  This might be done as well using a pipe on /tmp and
00035      * making the command 'cat' the pipe: when ssh runs, it
00036      * runs the command 'cat' on the pipe and hangs on read.
00037      *  Then we just need a thread to open the pipe, put the
00038      * password and close the pipe.
00039      *  This other way the password is never wirtten down.
00040      * But, OTOH, the file life is so ephemeral that most
00041      * of the time it will only exist in the internal system
00042      * cache, so this approach is not that bad either.
00043      *
00044      *  @param remote   The remote end to run the command, in
00045      *                      the form 'user@host:port' (you may
00046      *                      omit the 'user@' or ':port' parts
00047      *                      if the default values [i.e. same user
00048      *                      or standard port] are OK).
00049      *  @param password The remote password. Note that if direct
00050      *                      RSA/DSA/.shosts/.rhosts login is enabled
00051      *                      then the password should be ignored as
00052      *                      SSH should not run the ASKPASS command).
00053      *  @param command  The command to execute on the remote end
00054      *                      NOTE: if you want to use redirection, the
00055      *                      entire remote command line should be 
00056      *                      enclosed in additional quotes!
00057      *  @param status   Optional, this will hold the termination
00058      *                      status of SSH after invocation, which
00059      *                      should be the exit status of the remote
00060      *                      command or 255 if an error occurred
00061      *  @return void
00062      */
00063     function ssh_passthru($remote, $password, $command, &$status)
00064     {
00065         global $debug;
00066 
00067         // Setup environment
00068         umask(0077);
00069         $tmpfname = tempnam('/tmp', 'phpSsh');
00070         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00071         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname."\n";
00072         
00073         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00074         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00075 
00076         // make askpass command
00077         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00078         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00079         fputs($fp, "rm -f $tmpfname\n");
00080         fclose($fp);
00081         // go
00082         if (isset($status))
00083             passthru("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", $status);
00084         else
00085             passthru("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command");
00086     }
00087     
00088     /**
00089      *  Execute a remote command using SSH
00090      *
00091      *  This function sort of mimics rexec(3) using SSH as the transport
00092      * protocol.
00093      *
00094      *  The function returns the exit status of the remote command, and
00095      * appends the remote job output to an optional argument.
00096      *
00097      *  This function is intended to be used as a one-time
00098      * all-at-once non-interactive execution mechanism which
00099      * will run the command remotely and return its output.
00100      *
00101      *  If you try to issue an interactive command using this
00102      * function, all you will get is unneccessary trouble. So
00103      * don't!
00104      *
00105      *  @param remote   The remote end to run the command, in
00106      *                      the form 'user@host:port' (you may
00107      *                      omit the 'user@' or ':port' parts
00108      *                      if the default values [i.e. same user
00109      *                      or standard port] are OK).
00110      *  @param password The remote password. Note that if direct
00111      *                      RSA/DSA/.shosts/.rhosts login is enabled
00112      *                      then the password should be ignored as
00113      *                      SSH should not run the ASKPASS command).
00114      *  @param command  The command to execute on the remote end
00115      *                      NOTE: if you want to use redirection, the
00116      *                      entire remote command line should be 
00117      *                      enclosed in additional quotes!
00118      *  @param output   Optional, the collated (stdout+stderr) output 
00119      *                      of the remote command.
00120      *  @return status  will hold the termination
00121      *                      status of SSH after invocation, which
00122      *                      should be the exit status of the remote
00123      *                      command or 255 if an error occurred
00124      */
00125     function ssh_exec($remote, $password, $command, &$out)
00126     {
00127         global $debug;
00128 
00129         umask(0077);
00130         $tmpfname = tempnam('/tmp', 'phpSsh');
00131         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00132         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname . "\n";
00133 
00134         putenv('DISPLAY=none:0.');
00135         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00136         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00137         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00138         fputs($fp, "rm -f $tmpfname\n");
00139         fclose($fp);
00140         exec("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", $out, $retval);
00141 
00142     }

00144     /**
00145      *  Copy a file or directory from one source to a destination
00146      *
00147      *  This function copies source to dest, where one of them is a
00148      * local filespec and the other a remote filespec of the form
00149      * [user@]host:path
00150      *
00151      *  If the original source is a directory, it will be copied
00152      * recursively to destination (hence easing file transfers).
00153      *
00154      *  The function returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.
00155      *
00156      *  @param origin   The origin path, of the form
00157      *                  [user@][host][:port]path
00158      *                  You may omit the optional sections if
00159      *                  the default values (local username, local
00160      *                  host, standard SSH port) are OK
00161      *
00162      *  @param destination      The destination path, of the form
00163      *                  [user@][host][:port]path
00164      *                  You may omit the optional sections if
00165      *                  the default values (local username, local
00166      *                  host, standard SSH port) are OK
00167      *
00168      *  @parm password  The password to use to connect to the remote
00169      *                  end of the copy (be it the origin or the
00170      *                  destination, it's all the same). If connection
00171      *                  is automatic by some means (.shosts or RSA/DSA
00172      *                  authentication) then it should be ignored and
00173      *                  any password should do.
00174      *
00175      *  @return status  TRUE if all went well, or FALSE on failure.
00176      */
00177     function ssh_copy($origin, $destination, $password)
00178     {
00179         global $debug;
00180 
00181         umask(0077);
00182         $tmpfname = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh");
00183         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00184         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00185         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00186         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00187         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00188         fputs($fp, "rm $tmpfname\n");
00189         fclose($fp);
00190         system("scp -pqrC $origin $destination", $status);
00191         if ($status == 0)
00192             return TRUE;
00193         else
00194             return FALSE;
00195     }
00196 
00197     /**
00198      *  Open an SSH connection to a remote site with a shell to run 
00199      * interactive commands
00200      *
00201      *  Connects to a remote host and opens an interactive shell session
00202      * with NO controlling terminal.
00203      *
00204      *  Returns a process_control array which contains the process resource
00205      * ID and an the standard file descriptors which the caller may use to
00206      * interact with the remote shell.
00207      *
00208      *  @param remote   The remote end to run the shell, in
00209      *                      the form 'user@host:port' (you may
00210      *                      omit the 'user@' or ':port' parts
00211      *                      if the default values [i.e. same user
00212      *                      or standard port] are OK).
00213      *  @param password The remote password. Note that if direct
00214      *                      RSA/DSA/.shosts/.rhosts login is enabled
00215      *                      then the password should be ignored as
00216      *                      SSH should not run the ASKPASS command).
00217      */
00218     function ssh_open_shell($remote, $password)
00219     {   
00220         global $debug;
00221 
00222         // Open a child process with the 'proc_open' function. 
00223         //
00224         // Some tricks: we must open the connection using '-x' to disable
00225         // X11 forwarding, and use '-t -t' to avoid SSH generating an error
00226         // because we are not connected to any terminal.
00227         //
00228         // NOTE: if the web server is trusted remotely (i.e. it's SSH public 
00229         // key is accepted in ~user@host:.ssh/authorized_keys) then any 
00230         // password will do.
00231 
00232         // Prepare I/O
00233         umask(0077);
00234         // NOTE, here we try leaving log files behind, but it is not
00235         // neccessary
00236         if ($debug) {
00237             $child_stdout = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-".getmypid()."-1-");
00238             $child_stderr = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-".getmypid()."-2-");
00239         } else {
00240             $child_stdout = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00241             $child_stderr = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00242         }
00243         $descriptorspec = array(
00244             0 => array("pipe", "r"),  // connect child's stdin to the read end of a pipe
00245             1 => array("file", $child_stdout, "a"),
00246             2 => array("file", $child_stderr, "a")
00247         );
00248 
00249         // prepare password
00250         umask(0077);
00251         $tmpfname = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00252         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00253         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname . "\n";
00254 
00255         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00256         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00257         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00258         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00259         fputs($fp, "rm $tmpfname\n");
00260         fclose($fp);
00261 
00262         if ($debug) echo "ssh -x -t -t $remote<br />\n";
00263         $process = proc_open("ssh -x -t -t $remote", 
00264                          $descriptorspec,
00265                          $pipes);
00266         
00267         // check status
00268         if (!is_resource($process)) 
00269         {
00270             letal("SSH::connect", "cannot connect to the remote host");
00271             return;
00272         }
00273         if ($debug) echo "proc_open done<br />\n";
00274 
00275         // $pipes now looks like this:
00276         //   0 => writeable handle connected to child stdin
00277         
00278         // Open child's stdin and stdout
00279         $pipes[1] = fopen($child_stdout, "r");
00280         $pipes[2] = fopen($child_stderr, "r");
00281         
00282         // Should we leave this to the user?
00283         // set to non-blocking and avoid having to call fflush
00284         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[0], FALSE);
00285         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[1], FALSE);
00286         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[2], FALSE);
00287         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[0], 0);
00288         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[1], 0);
00289         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[2], 0);
00290 
00291         // We now have a connection to the remote SSH
00292         // Server which we may use to send commands/receive output
00293         $p = array('process' => $process
00294                     ,'std_in' => $pipes[0]
00295                     ,'std_out' => $pipes[1]
00296                     ,'std_err' => $pipes[2] 
00297                     ,'stdout_file' => $child_stdout
00298                     ,'stderr_file' => $child_stderr
00299                    );
00300         if ($debug)  {
00301             echo "process descriptor array is \n";
00302             print_r($p);
00303         }
00304         return $p;
00305     }

00307     /**
00308      *  Open an SSH connection to run an interactive command on a remote
00309      * site
00310      *
00311      *  Connects to a remote host and runs an interactive command
00312      * with NO controlling terminal.
00313      *
00314      *  Returns a process_control array which contains the process resource
00315      * ID and an the standard file descriptors which the caller may use to
00316      * interact with the remote shell.
00317      */
00318     function ssh_open_command($remote, $password, $command)
00319     {   
00320         global $debug;
00321 
00322         // Open a child process with the 'proc_open' function. 
00323         //
00324         // Some tricks: we must open the connection using '-x' to disable
00325         // X11 forwarding, and use '-t -t' to avoid SSH generating an error
00326         // because we are not connected to any terminal.
00327         //
00328         // NOTE: if the web server is trusted remotely (i.e. it's SSH public 
00329         // key is accepted in ~user@host:.ssh/authorized_keys) then any 
00330         // password will do.
00331 
00332         // Prepare I/O
00333         umask(0077);
00334         // NOTE, here we try leaving log files behind, but it is not
00335         // neccessary
00336         if ($debug) {
00337             $child_stdout = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-".getmypid()."-1-");
00338             $child_stderr = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-".getmypid()."-2-");
00339         } else {
00340             $child_stdout = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00341             $child_stderr = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00342         }
00343         $descriptorspec = array(
00344             0 => array("pipe", "r"),  // connect child's stdin to the read end of a pipe
00345             1 => array("file", $child_stdout, "a"),
00346             2 => array("file", $child_stderr, "a")
00347         );
00348 
00349         // prepare password
00350         umask(0077);
00351         $tmpfname = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00352         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00353         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname . "\n";
00354 
00355         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00356         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00357         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00358         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00359         fputs($fp, "rm $tmpfname\n");
00360         fclose($fp);
00361 
00362         if ($debug) echo "ssh -x -t -t $remote $command<br />\n";
00363         $process = proc_open("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", 
00364                          $descriptorspec,
00365                          $pipes);
00366         
00367         // check status
00368         if (!is_resource($process)) 
00369         {
00370             letal("SSH::connect", "cannot connect to the remote host");
00371             return;
00372         }
00373         if ($debug) echo "proc_open done<br />\n";
00374 
00375         // $pipes now looks like this:
00376         //   0 => writeable handle connected to child stdin
00377         
00378         // Open child's stdin and stdout
00379         $pipes[1] = fopen($child_stdout, "r");
00380         $pipes[2] = fopen($child_stderr, "r");
00381         
00382         // Should we leave this to the user?
00383         // set to non-blocking and avoid having to call fflush
00384         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[0], FALSE);
00385         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[1], FALSE);
00386         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[2], FALSE);
00387         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[0], 0);
00388         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[1], 0);
00389         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[2], 0);
00390 
00391         // We now have a connection to the remote SSH
00392         // Server which we may use to send commands/receive output
00393         $p = array('process' => $process
00394                     ,'std_in' => $pipes[0]
00395                     ,'std_out' => $pipes[1]
00396                     ,'std_err' => $pipes[2] 
00397                     ,'stdout_file' => $child_stdout
00398                     ,'stderr_file' => $child_stderr
00399                    );
00400         if ($debug)  {
00401             echo "process descriptor array is \n";
00402             print_r($p);
00403         }
00404         return $p;
00405     }

00407     /**
00408      * Close an SSH interactive session
00409      */
00410     function ssh_close($p)
00411     {
00412         global $debug;
00413         
00414             fwrite($p['std_in'], "\n");
00415             fwrite($p['std_in'], "logout\n");
00416             fflush($p['std_in']);
00417             fclose($p['std_in']); fclose($p['std_out']); fclose($p['std_err']);
00418             if ($debug) echo "pipes closed\n";
00419             proc_close($p['process']);
00420             if ($debug) echo "process closed\n";
00421     }
00422     
00423     function ssh_close_bck($p)
00424     {
00425         global $debug;
00426         if ($debug) {
00427             echo "ssh_close\n";
00428             print_r($p);
00429         }
00430 
00431         fwrite($p['std_in'], 'logout\n'); 
00432         fflush($p['std_in']);
00433         fclose($p['std_in']);
00434         fclose($p['std_out']);
00435         fclose($p['std_err']);
00436         if ($debug)
00437             echo "pipes closed\n";
00438         return proc_close($p['process']);
00439     }

00442     /**
00443      *  Execute a remore command and keep an unidirectional stream
00444      * contact with it.
00445      *
00446      *  This routine mimics 'popen()' but uses ssh to connect to
00447      * a remote host and run the requested command.
00448      */
00449     function ssh_popen($remote, $password, $command, $mode)
00450     {
00451         global $debug;
00452 
00453         // Setup environment
00454         umask(0077);
00455         $tmpfname = tempnam('/tmp', 'phpSsh-');
00456         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00457         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname."\n";
00458         
00459         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00460         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00461 
00462         // make askpass command
00463         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00464         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00465         fputs($fp, "rm -f $tmpfname\n");
00466         fclose($fp);
00467         // go
00468         return popen("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", $mode);
00469     }
00470     
00471     function ssh_pclose($f)
00472     {
00473         return pclose($f);
00474     }
